Description: Three fragments of fine quality, weft-faced compound silk (1:2 twill); Pink and cream; Repeating design of stylised rosettes in circles and trefoils in circles in alternate rows, on a finely chequered ground; a) has part of a border with a plain cream band preceded by a band of larger chequers; Warp: undyed cream/white silk, Z twist, c.60 tpc; Weft: undyed cream/white silk and pink/red silk, no twist, c.72 passes of 1 thread of each colour per cm, undyed silk in plain band a thicker yarn. no twist at c.35 passes per cm of 2 cream hreads; Edges: raged
Curator's comments: See also OA.756; Previous location Cupboard 64; Probably from a tunic; Early date indicated by the small scale of the design and the very fine quality; May have been a warp fringe beyond the plain band, compare to OA756; At upper edge of little squares one red thread seems to be paired with one undyed thread; Fragments in other collections include VA 338-1887 (Kendrick 852) and Lyon, Musee Historique des Tissus 25.233; Forrer, R. "Romische und Byzantinische Seiden-Textilien ans dem Graberfelde von Achmim-Panoplois", Strasburg 1891, pls IX 4 and XV 2 (BL KTC 26b.9); Information from Hero Granger-Taylor (26/3/1992)
Bibliographic references: Buckton 1994 / Byzantium: Treasures of Byzantine art and culture from British collections (49)
Muthesius 1997 / Byzantine Silk Weaving, AD 400 to AD 1200 (M417a)
Condition: Fair; a) badly worn, colour comparatively good
Acquisition notes: Exact details of acquisition unknown, but fragments of same cloth in other collections recorded as coming from Akhmim in Egypt.
